project.title: Mountain City - Web Video Series (@164cray network)
project.author: Scott Grocott x- @scott_grocott
project.description: Mountain City is on the island of Autopia. Autopia is a socially stratified island nation where car culture dominates daily life. The city is known for its towering skyscrapers, sprawling highways, and dense urban environment filled with neon lights and bustling streets. The story follows a lone protagonist navigating the dangerous underbelly of Mountain City, uncovering conspiracies tied to the powerful automotive families that control the city's economy and politics.
production_design: Miniature live sets with practical effects
Audio/Script production approach. Modeled after radio drama and 'South Park'.
It's all about the cars: custom builds, stunts, chases. Anytime we can focus on vehicles, we do. Car action first and narrative second.
car culture as worldbuilding: the social dynamics, fashion, music, and architecture are all influenced by automotive themes.
series_arc: The whole series will be in 3 acts.

Act 1 introduces the world and characters.Most of the primary action will take place in the wooded outskirts of the city,with occasional cutaways to the city for establishing various elements. The primary location is the 'A.O.K. Kampground' this camping facility is a more affordable, open to everyone (meaning all makes and models of cars). The campground,is ajacent to a giant recreational area for auto enthusiasts. Campers bring their vehicle to enjoy all kinds of auto performance activity.

Act 2 Takes our main character from the outskirts into the heart of Mountain City. Here, the protagonist uncovers deeper conspiracies involving the powerful automotive families that control the city. High-speed chases through neon-lit streets, daring escapes, and intense confrontations define this act.This culminates in a showdown with leader of the Ferrari family, revealing their plans to monopolize the city's automotive industry.

Act 3 Adds the final twist in that the city is taken over by a new more powerful boss.'Chad Boss' to be exact. Chad moves in with his Lamborghini operation (up until this point in the series Lamborghini has not be seen or spoken of because Chad had not been called in yet) and begins to battle the powers that be to get the city under his control in a high-stakes showdown that reshapes Mountain City.

characters.name: Edward Van Heflen

car.base: rusty, Mater-inspired original character pieced together from junkyard scraps
car.condition: barely runs, backfires constantly, laughed at by everyone
car.emotional_value: the only thing he truly owns; every mod is a promise to himself and his missing brother

jobs: Cashier at the kampground general store
characters.living_situation: Permanently parked, beat-to-hell travel trailer behind the store

family_backstory.father: Low-tier commuter-class driver, died in a suspicious high-speed crash when Eddie was 9 – officially ruled 'driver error', but Eddie never believed it
family_backstory.mother: Worked double shifts at a Tortellini-owned parts warehouse until her health broke; now lives off-island

older_brother.name: Alex Van Heflen
older_brother.last_seen: Three years ago, after bragging he’d been offered a secret test drive for one of the big families
older_brother.clues_left_behind: A half-finished turbo blueprint and an old leather toolkit Eddie still keeps under his bed

characters.core_desire: To be handed the keys to a real dynasty race car just once – not for fame, but to prove to himself (and to whatever’s left of Lucas) that he’s fast enough

emotional_core.primary_wound: Feels he’s the reason Lucas vanished – thinks his brother took a dangerous gig to get Eddie a shot that never came
emotional_core.daily_pain: Sweeping cigarette butts off the same tracks where legends are made their name, selling energy drinks to the kids who already have what he wants
emotional_core.hidden_fear: That he isn’t actually fast – that all the daydreams are just delusion and Lucas died for nothing

characters.current_state: Quiet, watchful, polite to a fault. Speaks softly, listens hard, and can strip an alternator in four minutes flat. Zero confidence behind the wheel of anything faster than a golf cart, but his hands don’t shake when he’s holding a wrench.

characters.name: A.O.K. Kampground
characters.position: on the outermost edge of the massive Autopia National Motor Recreation Area
characters.description: A sprawling, no-frills campground for gearheads who can't afford the resorts. Dusty lots, fire rings made from old wheels, communal tool sheds, and a single general store. It's the only place on the entire rec area where unlicensed commuters and independents are allowed to stay overnight.
characters.relationship_to_rec_area: sits just outside the gated perimeter of the Autopia National Motor Recreation Area (a national-park-sized complex of tracks, resorts, and proving grounds). Wealthy dynasties and tourists use the luxury resorts adjacent to the park; A.O.K. is where the working stiffs park their trailers and watch the skyline of neon tracks glow at night.
daily_sights: dynasty racing teams hauling Hot Wheels Ferrari fleets through the gates
rich tourists in Mini GT and premium replicas checking into five-star auto-resorts
Canyon Crossing off-roaders roaring past on their way to the trails
Mountain City street racers sneaking in for late-night practice sessions
characters.protagonist_perspective: every shift he sees the life he wants on the other side of the fence—while he's stuck mowing the grass and selling energy drinks to the people living it

characters.vibe: Stranger Things tech misfits meet Goonies-style gearhead rebels

members.name: Rusty
members.backstory: Prodigy tinkerer from Bay City. His family’s Peugeot garage was fire-bombed by Tortellini enforcers over unpaid 'protection.' He escaped with only a duffel of tools and a lifelong hatred of the dynasties. Now he turns scrap into weapons, traps, and impossible mods while quietly tracking every family shipment that rolls past the kampground.
members.how_they_met: Met the protagonist during a late-night meltdown of the protagonist’s barely-running Frankenstein car. Rusty watched him stubbornly try to repair it alone, saw the same desperation he grew up with, and stepped in. The 'fix' was dangerous, brilliant, and held together with three bolts and hope—marking the start of their partnership.
traits: Combines scrap tech with car parts
Dark, sarcastic comic relief with sudden strokes of genius
members.interaction_with_protagonist: Constantly upgrades the protagonist’s Frankenstein car, pushing wild ideas that either win races or nearly kill them—usually both.

members.name: Echo
members.backstory: Former mainland corporate data analyst who discovered the dynasties were rigging fuel prices island-wide. When she tried to leak it, they put a bounty on her. She fled to the kampground, rewired the old CB tower into a surveillance net, and now watches everything without ever being seen.
members.how_they_met: The protagonist discovered Echo long before he actually met her—through anonymous warnings scribbled on receipts, marked maps tucked under his trailer door, and mysterious static bursts on the CB radio. Eventually he caught her calibrating a homemade antenna behind the general store. She said only one sentence: 'You're standing in a blind spot,' and from then on she quietly watched over him.
traits: Master of scavenged surveillance and hacked police scanners
Sees patterns no one else notices
members.interaction_with_protagonist: Feeds the protagonist cryptic warnings and shortcuts, speaking in half-sentences that somehow always save his skin.

members.name: Nova
members.backstory: Grew up in the Port Injection slums running bets for the Kim family’s underground fight club. Kicked out (and nearly killed) for refusing to throw a match. He’s been plotting revenge ever since, turning every race into a chess move against the dynasties.
members.how_they_met: Nova first noticed the protagonist during an impromptu illegal time-trial near the edge of Mountain City. The protagonist wasn’t racing—he was quietly watching from behind a fence. Nova clocked his hunger instantly. Later that night, after a small scuffle with some dynasty punks, Nova saw the protagonist stand his ground despite being scared out of his mind. Nova decided he’d found a wildcard worth backing.
traits: Natural leader who drags everyone into glorious trouble
members.interaction_with_protagonist: Sees the protagonist as the perfect wildcard and constantly maneuvers him into bigger, riskier plays against the families.

members.name: Axel
members.backstory: Former off-road champion blacklisted by the Boss family after he refused to fix a Velocity Flats record run. They slashed his tires and left him in the desert. He walked out three days later towing his wrecked truck with a winch he built from junk. Now he maps every hidden trail on Autopia and lives for the next impossible stunt.
members.how_they_met: Axel met the protagonist when he caught him trying—and failing spectacularly—to navigate a forbidden back trail on a junky scooter. Instead of laughing, Axel admired the guts it took. He tossed the kid the keys to his beat-up runner truck and said, 'If you’re gonna crash something, crash something worth the story.' It was the protagonist’s first time driving a real machine.
members.interaction_with_protagonist: The first person to ever let the protagonist drive a real race car; pushes him harder than anyone, believing the kid’s got champion blood.

members.name: Maggie
members.backstory: Daughter of a legendary independent fabricator who died when a faulty engine she helped design exploded during a test. The dynasties covered it up and blamed her family. She carries the guilt, but also every blueprint her father ever drew, and she’s determined to build something that will make the families remember her name.
members.how_they_met: They met when the protagonist found Maggie rummaging through the scrappers’ pile behind the kampground workshop, hunting for a very specific bolt pattern from a discontinued engine. They bonded instantly over mutual underdog dreams and shared grief—hers for her father, his for a life he’s never been allowed to touch. She became the first to tell him he wasn’t dreaming too big.
members.interaction_with_protagonist: The emotional anchor; constantly reminds him his dream is worth chasing and quietly sketches mods for the day he finally gets his shot.

characters.group_dynamic: Five kampground outcasts who turned a dusty trailer park into a rebel workshop and war room. They fight with brains, scrap, and pure nerve, rallying around the protagonist’s quiet dream of one day driving for real—knowing that if he ever gets the keys, they all rise together.

characters: primary antagonist: Joey Tortellini (Ferrari Family Leader)

autopia.description: A large island nation in the middle of the ocean. Autopia is a socially stratified and car culture dominates daily life. A port city, an inland desert, a mountain filled northern region (The location of Mountain City), a large deep canyon region in the desert. Very mysterious

profile.name: Autopia
profile.motto: Vincit Qui Patitur (He Who Endures, Wins... usually the race)

geography.summary: A terra-formed diverse biome island designed specifically for automotive testing and lifestyle. The island is ringed by 'The Beltway' (Highway 1) and divided into 5 distinct 'Driving Zones'.

regions.name: Desert Flats
description: Desert Flats-sounds like this vast, sun-baked expanse just past Mountain City's edges, where the land stretches out flat and endless, dotted with wind-worn rocks and forgotten trails. It's got that lonely, timeless feel, right? The kind of place where old ranches cling to life, dust devils dance in the heat, and maybe a lone inventor tinkers in a shed full of half-finished machines.

The racing scene fits perfectly, turning those endless flats into a high-stakes playground for speed junkies and daredevils. Imagine souped-up mini hot rods barreling across the salt, kicking up dust clouds that shimmer in the heat, crowds gathered under patched-up awnings, betting on who'll make it to the end without their engine seizing from the dust.

regions.name: Bay City
description: Bay City-coastal counterpart to Mountain City's inland vibes. A miniature port town. Bay's the living room, where inland and coast share space on one tiny peninsula. Mountains frame it, but the water's what makes it breathe.
Bay City-miniature coastal racing town. Drift culture rules here, with cars screeching around tight bends, drifting sideways past neon lights and harbor cranes, salt air mixing with tire smoke.

regions.name: Harbor Town
description: Harbor Town-Bay City's rough-and-tumble cousin. The kind of dockside sprawl where the air's thick with salt, diesel, and low-end bass. Muscle cars are kings here, their V8s rumbling like thunder off rusted freighters. This is where every car on the island continent makes landfall-creaking gangways, tarps flapping in the salt wind. Cars roll down planks straight into the grit, tires hissing against wet concrete, grease and sweat in the air as mechanics and drivers size each other up before the first race even starts.

regions.name: Canyon Crossing
description: Canyon Crossing-that's the wild frontier carved into Autopia's craggy spine. Imagine endless red rock canyons, wide enough to swallow whole RV convoys and dotted with switchback trails where 4x4s claw their way up sheer cliffs, tires spitting gravel and dust. It's a haven for off-road junkies, those rugged souls who live for the roar of a big-block diesel echoing off canyon walls, the thrill of jumping ravines in tricked-out rigs. Picture massive campfires under star-drenched skies, RVs parked in half-moon clusters like tiny pioneer settlements, and dust trails marking the paths of the latest canyon daredevils. This is where sanity takes a backseat to the pull of the wild

regions.name: Everglades Jungle
description: Everglades Jungle-the humid, pulse-quickening heart of Autopia's night scene, a twisted mashup of tangled mangroves, glowing neon, and full-moon key to key style small connected island races.

regions.name: Port Injection
regions.description: The capital city. A neon-drenched coastal metropolis where zoning laws require every building to have a garage on the first floor. Traffic lights are drag trees. The police drive high-speed interceptors (GTRs/Porsches).
landmarks: The Turbo Terminal (Shipping docks for vehicle imports)
The Spiral (A massive multi-level parking structure/residential complex)

regions.name: The Gasket Gulch
regions.description: The lawless interior. No paved roads exist here. Fuel is currency. The inhabitants live in fortified scrapyards. It is the graveyard for cars that fail inspection in the city.
landmarks: Injector Falls (An oasis, but for fuel refining)

regions.name: Apex Peaks
regions.description: A winding mountain range that separates the coast from the desert. Home to the wealthy and the skilled. The roads are technical, narrow, and often icy. 'The Pass' is the only paved route through the mountains.
landmarks: The Hairpin Hotel (Luxury resort at the summit)

regions.name: Torque Timberlands
regions.description: A dense, wet forest region. Travel here is measured in 'obstacles per mile' rather than MPH. The culture is cooperative; drivers must use winches and recovery gear to help each other traverse the terrain.
landmarks: The Bog (An infamous mud pit that swallows cars)

regions.name: Velocity Flats
regions.description: A massive, flat expanse of white salt. There are no speed limits because there are no lanes. This is the testing ground for experimental engineering and land speed records.
landmarks: Crash Site Alpha (A monument to failed attempts)

roads.Highway 1 (The Beltway): A 12-lane superhighway orbiting the island. 6 lanes clockwise, 6 lanes counter-clockwise. Minimum speed limit: 80 MPH.
roads.Route 666 (The Dragon): The mountain pass connecting Port Injection to The Gasket Gulch. 300 corners in 30 miles.
roads.The Overland Trail: A GPS-marked dirt route connecting the Timberlands to the Desert.

services.Fuel: Available everywhere. 100 Octane is standard. 87 Octane is illegal.
services.Repair: Every town center is a mechanic shop. Restaurants usually double as oil-change pits.

lawEnforcement.Off-Road Response: Ford Raptors & Local Motors Rally Fighters.
lawEnforcement.Philosophy: They don't pull you over for speeding; they pull you over for driving a boring car.

AutopiaCanon.coreLaw: All vehicles are manufactured on The Mainland. Autopia only drives, worships, modifies, and wages war over them.
AutopiaCanon.mainlandMyth: A fog-shrouded super-continent of endless factories that no Autopian has ever seen and returned unchanged.

dynasties.culturalRole: The endless horde — cheap, bright, disposable. Fuel of street races and playground wars.
dynasties.signatureTrait: Redline wheels that scream like banshees
dynasties.arrivalMethod: Dropped by the millions in orange-track cargo planes

dynasties.culturalRole: Honest daily drivers. The backbone of delivery fleets and family garages.
Flashy but hollow. Loved by the nouveau-riche of Torque Timberlands.
Police interceptors and Hollywood heroes. Every cop car on the island.
dynasties.signatureTrait: Accurate light bars and correct decals

dynasties.culturalRole: All-metal purists. Too heavy to drift properly.
dynasties.signatureTrait: Real rubber tires and tiny 426 Hemi decals
dynasties.arrivalMethod: Velvet-lined crates, one at a time

dynasties.culturalRole: Stanced drifting monks of Apex Peaks.
dynasties.signatureTrait: Photo-etched grilles and tiny brake calipers

dynasties.culturalRole: The untouchables. A single AUTOart can buy a mountain pass.
dynasties.arrivalMethod: Delivered only upon the death of a dynasty leader

dynasties.culturalRole: Understated perfection. Faster than physics allows.
dynasties.arrivalMethod: Bullet train that never fully stops

dynasties.culturalRole: You don’t buy a Kyosho; it chooses you.
dynasties.signatureTrait: Hand-polished until it reflects your sins

dynasties.culturalRole: Liberty Walk widebodies and rocket-bunny gangs.
dynasties.arrivalMethod: Hidden in speaker boxes and fake IKEA flats

dealershipFamilies.description: Each ethnic family owns a dealership + restaurant tied to national cuisine and car manufacturer. Economic and political dynasties shape Mountain City culture. Families control both racing fleets (performance-focused basics) and showroom collections (premium status symbols).
dealershipFamilies.coreRule: Family last names correspond to national cuisine; manufacturer matches origin country. Each family monopolizes their brand across all quality tiers.

workingClass.description: Regular citizens of Autopia who drive unlicensed fantasy cars not affiliated with any dealership family. These are the true independents - the working class, the nobodies, the underdogs.
workingClass.vehicleTypes: Hot Wheels originals (Bone Shaker, Twin Mill, Deora II), Matchbox generics (unlicensed trucks, vans, service vehicles), Maisto fantasy models
workingClass.socialStatus: Lowest tier - no family protection, no brand loyalty, must earn all respect
workingClass.locations: A.O.K. Kampground (accepts all makes/models), independent shops, alleys, back streets
workingClass.narrativeRole: Ultimate underdogs - when an unlicensed car wins a race, it's a major upset that threatens the family power structure

1_64_scale_dicast_brands.brief_history: Founded in 1968 by Mattel co-founder Elliot Handler in the USA to rival Matchbox; revolutionized 1:64 diecast with fast, stylized 'hot rod' designs and orange tracks. Acquired Matchbox in 1997; produces billions annually, blending toys and collectibles.

Burgundy with Firestone and Castrol liveries, number 34

White with black and purple pinstripes, white walls
Red and black with gray wheels

1_64_scale_dicast_brands.brief_history: Launched in 1953 by Lesney Products in the UK as pocket-sized diecast toys; acquired by Mattel in 1997 after Lesney's 1982 bankruptcy. Known for realistic vehicles; shifted production to Asia in the 1980s.

inventory.color: Deep dark metal flake blue-green, almost black

modifications: Remove existing tampos and replace with Mountain City appropriate graphics
Doorless, topless configuration - ready for outdoor action

1_64_scale_dicast_brands.brief_history: Founded in 1961 in France by Jean Sablon; focuses on everyday and emergency vehicles. Acquired by Migao Group (China) in 2017; emphasizes play value with durable designs.
Established in 1967 in Hong Kong as May Cheong; Maisto brand debuted in 1990 for affordable diecast. Acquired Bburago in 2005; produces budget-friendly replicas with global licensing.
Founded in 2002 in the USA by Kevin Davey; specializes in licensed pop culture and muscle car replicas. Known for high-detail blister-pack series; targets adult collectors.
Launched in 1998 in Hong Kong by Gateway; pioneered composite (ABS + diecast) for precision. Associated with UT Models; focuses on premium exotics and racers.
Founded in 1999 in California by Jack and May Li; started with Thunder Crusher trucks, exploded with DUB City urban customs. Acquired by Simba Dickie Group in 2021; blends toys and collectibles.
Started in 1982 by JRI Inc. in New Jersey, USA; focused on 1950s-60s American classics. Acquired by Jakks Pacific in 1995; emphasized detail in blister packs.
Debuted in 1969 by Topper Toys in the USA as speed-focused rivals to Hot Wheels; revived in 1994 by Playing Mantis, then RC2/Tomy (discontinued 2013). Relaunched by Round 2 in 2016.
Founded in 2007 in California by Chris Leong (ex-Muscle Machines); targets overlooked 1950s-70s American iron with high detail. Emphasizes full-metal construction.
Established in 2014 in Hong Kong by car enthusiasts; specializes in JDM and race cars. Gained traction with hobby-grade details; partners with iXO for partworks.
Launched mid-2010s as a 1:64 line of TrueScale Miniatures (founded 2006 in Hong Kong by Glen Chou); focuses on exotics and JDM with full diecast bodies. Affordable premium alternative.
Founded in 2000 in France by Hugo Ripert (ex-Vitesse/Ixo); pioneered affordable resin racers, especially Le Mans backmarkers. Expanded to diecast; produced in China/Madagascar.
Started in 1992 in Australia by Trevor and Bev Young as a Kyosho distributor; began own production in 1998. Specializes in Aussie V8 Supercars; changed hands post-2006.
Founded in 1963 in Japan; pioneered RC models, entered diecast in 1992. Known for high-end replicas; licenses BMW exclusively for dealership sales.
Established in 2000 in China as a plastic toy maker; pivoted to licensed RC/diecast by 2005. Holds global BMW RC exclusivity; focuses on affordable replicas.
Founded in 1979 in Hong Kong; shifted production to China in the 1980s. Budget-friendly with pullback motors; licenses 40+ brands for global distribution.
Launched 1974 in Italy as Martoys by Besana brothers (ex-Mebetoys); renamed 1976. Pioneered 1:18 diecast; bankrupt 2005, revived by Maisto in 2007.
Debuted 1970 in Japan by Takara (now Tomy); emphasizes realistic JDM vehicles. Limited Vintage line adds premium details; huge domestic following.
Founded mid-2010s in Hong Kong; niche for modified JDM and LB Works customs. High-detail resin/diecast hybrids; popular in Asia-Pacific collector scene.
Launched early 2010s in Hong Kong; affordable racers and tuners. Gained cult status for quick releases; focuses on endurance and GT cars.
Founded 1946 in Germany by Richard Siewer; post-WWII focus on farm/commercial vehicles. Family-owned; emphasizes durable, realistic toys.
Established 1953 in France; revived 2000s after bankruptcy. Specializes in French classics; high-detail resin/diecast for collectors.
Founded 1956 in the UK by Mettoy; aviation roots. Acquired by Hornby in 1980s; focuses on licensed racers and milestones.
Started 1912 in Germany as Schreyer & Co.; post-WWII diecast revival. Premium German engineering focus; owned by Simba Dickie since 1990s.
Founded 2000s in Hong Kong; niche for rare prototypes and concepts. Resin-focused with diecast accents; small-batch for enthusiasts.
Launched 2010s in China; hyper-detailed exotics and tuners. Affordable premium; rapid growth via online collector communities.
Early 2010s USA brand; custom lowriders and street rods. Collaborates with artists; emphasizes ride height and stance.
Founded 2010s in Hong Kong; JDM stance and drift focus. Diecast with resin parts; popular for modified Skylines and Silvias.
Mid-2010s Chinese newcomer; budget racers and hypercars. Quick iterations; appeals to entry-level premium collectors.
Revival line from 2000s under Tomica; reissues vintage Japanese classics with modern details. Collector-exclusive.
Founded 1976 in Japan; JDM and Super GT specialist. Bankrupt 2020s but legacy endures via reissues; high-fidelity racers.
Started 1950s in USA as slot car maker; diecast since 2000s. Acquired by Round 2; muscle car focus.
Founded 2005 in USA; revives classics like Johnny Lightning. Parent to Auto World; emphasizes nostalgia.

season_1_outline.title: The Forest Tracks
season_1_outline.season_arc: Eddie Van Heflen goes from unknown A.O.K. groundskeeper to hot prospect courted by multiple dynasties while hunting the truth about his missing brother Alex. Ends with the crew committing to infiltrate Mountain City and confront Joey Tortellini.
season_1_outline.cliffhanger: Anonymous call from J.T. (Joey Tortellini) lures Eddie to Mountain City: 'Your brother asked too many questions.'

key_families.name: Tortellini Ferrari
key_families.approach: shadow puppet-master, never directly offers until finale

mini_arcs.title: Welcome to A.O.K.

episodes.title: First Shift
episodes.logline: On his first day back after winter break, Eddie works his double shift while watching family teams practice—dreaming of a life he’s never allowed to touch.

episodes.title: The Crew
episodes.logline: Eddie’s Frankenstein car breaks down; Rusty fixes it and introduces him to the ragtag crew of dynasty-burned outcasts.

episodes.title: Unlicensed
episodes.logline: Eddie watches Schneider BMW enforcers humiliate a working-class driver, confronting the brutal class system.

episodes.title: Velocity Flats Run
episodes.logline: Axel takes Eddie shotgun on an illegal midnight race—proving raw talent can beat money.

episodes.title: The Families
episodes.logline: A convoy of all 22 families rolls through A.O.K.; Eddie learns the full scope of their power.

episodes.title: Late Night at the Store
episodes.logline: Eddie opens up to Maggie about missing brother Alex and his fear he’ll never be fast enough.

mini_arcs.theme: World building, crew assembly, dream defined

mini_arcs.title: Clues in the Dust

episodes.title: The Blueprint
episodes.logline: Hidden turbo schematic in Alex’s old tools reveals first clue: 'Test run—Sector 7'.

episodes.title: Sector 7
episodes.logline: Eddie and Rusty break into abandoned Sector 7; discover covered-up crashes and barely escape security.

episodes.title: Nova’s Plan
episodes.logline: Nova enters Eddie in an underground race to build rep and gather intel.

episodes.title: First Race
episodes.logline: Eddie’s Frankenstein nearly explodes but he guts out a podium against independents.

episodes.title: Word Spreads
episodes.logline: Three families (Nakamura, Johnson, Kim) send scouts hunting 'the kid with the rust bucket'.

episodes.title: Three Offers
episodes.logline: Eddie receives formal recruitment pitches; Echo warns every contract is a cage.

mini_arcs.theme: Alex mystery surfaces, Eddie proves he can drive

episodes.title: Echo’s Network
episodes.logline: Echo’s intercepts reveal multiple families run secret 'test driver incidents'—Alex’s name appears in three.

episodes.title: The Warehouse
episodes.logline: Eddie and Maggie find redacted logs listing Alex as a contract tester.

episodes.title: Sal
episodes.logline: Paranoid ex-mechanic Sal reveals the families bury failed test drivers in paperwork, not hospitals.

episodes.title: Pressure
episodes.logline: Recruiting families turn hostile—threats, permit revocations, intimidation.

episodes.title: Maggie’s Gambit
episodes.logline: Crew builds a real race car from scrap to prove independence.

episodes.title: The Proving Run
episodes.logline: Eddie smashes the independent lap record at Echo Gorge—attracting Tortellini attention.

episodes.title: Summit Invitation
episodes.logline: Eddie is invited to the exclusive multi-family showcase at Summit Resorts.

episodes.title: Preparations
episodes.logline: Crew turns A.O.K. into a war room—tech, defenses, strategy.

episodes.title: The Showcase
episodes.logline: Brutal multi-heat race where prospects wreck each other for contracts.

episodes.title: Crash
episodes.logline: Johnson Ford driver intentionally wrecks Eddie—reveals hidden Tortellini body cam.

episodes.title: Questions
episodes.logline: Crew realizes Tortellini is secretly funding and manipulating other families’ test programs.

episodes.title: The Call (Season Finale)
episodes.logline: J.T. calls: 'Your brother asked too many questions. Come to Mountain City.' Eddie and crew decide to go in.

season_summary_by_blocks.1-6: World building, crew assembly, dreams defined
season_summary_by_blocks.7-12: Alex mystery surfaces, Eddie proves himself, families recruit
season_summary_by_blocks.19-24: Summit betrayal, Tortellini revealed, crew heads to Mountain City
